Award.AwardTitle: Learning Mathematics of the City in the City

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning Mathematics of the City in The City is an exploratory project that is developing teaching modules that engage high school students in learning mathematics and using the mathematics they learn. Using geo-spatial technologies, students explore their city with the purpose of collecting data they bring back to the formal classroom and use as part of their mathematics lessons. This place-based orientation is helping students connect their everyday and school mathematical thinking.

Researchers are investigating the impact of place-based learning on students' attitudes, beliefs, and self-concepts about mathematics in urban schools. Specifically, researchers want to understand how place-based learning helps students apply mathematics to address questions about their local environment. Researchers are also learning about the opportunities for teaching mathematics using carefully planned lessons enhanced by geo-spatial technologies. Data are being collected through student interviews, classroom observations, student questionnaires, and student work.

As the authors explain, "The use of familiar or engaging contexts is widely accepted as productive in the teaching and learning of mathematics." By working in urban neighborhoods with large populations of low-income families, this exploratory project is illustrating what can be done to engage students in mathematics and mathematical thinking. The products from the project include student materials, software adaptations, lesson plans, and findings from their research. These products enable further experimentation with place-based mathematics learning and lead the way for connecting mathematical activities in school and outside of school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project’s goals were to explore and develop resources and tools designed to enhance our knowledge base about the teaching and learning of mathematics in high schools in low-income, urban neighborhoods. 

The project explored a design research challenge of utilizing place-based education, enhanced with geospatial technologies, in the learning of mathematics. A design team comprised of mathematics education researchers, urban planners, and community organizers developed two 15 session learning modules that incorporated digital, geospatial tools to enable students to study themes with spatial perspectives. 

The first module, Local Lotto, was around the theme of the state lottery and was based on a study of combinatorics and probability to understand the set-up of local games of chance. Mapping tools were used to represent the impact of the lottery across a city and to gather information about local perspectives around participation in the lottery. This module was implemented in two rounds of piloting at a low-income high school.

The Local Lotto design experiences were featured in the Smithsonian's Cooper Hewitt Design Museum, as part of their Designing a Better America exhibit. Research about this module has been published in Cognition & Instruction, Harvard Educational Review, Mathematics Teaching in the Middle School, Journal of Digital Media Literacy, and findings have been shared at various researcher and practitioner conferences.  

The second module, Cash City, focused on the theme of alternative and mainstream financial institutions, with a perspective that emphasized the locations and densities of these various categories of institutions. Mapping tools were used to locate  institutions and to represent normalizations of variables, using traditional normalizations like per household or per square mile, as well as custom normalizations. Students used the mapping tools to explore these spatial distributions and to record their experiences in gathering field based data in their school's surroundings. We piloted this module in four rounds with revisions in collaboration with teachers at four low-income schools, in Brooklyn and Manhattan.  Research about this module has been published in the Journal for Urban Learning, Teaching, & Research, and the Journal of the Learning Sciences. Our improved data collection techniques allowed us to study, in detail, how students engage with mapping tools.

Two of our recent papers will support the field in future designs around place-based education, for mathematics and science as well as other disciplines. In particular, we have provided a design rubric in Harvard Educational Review and findings that relate to learning and mapping tools in the Journal of the Learning Sciences. 

Our research has engaged questions like how do students at schools in low-income, urban neighborhoods engage with the developed resources and tools? In particular, how do students apply mathematics to think critically about an aspect of the local environment? We have investigated how  student participation in place-based learning supports students to learn specific, target mathematical ideas, like combinatorics, sample space, basic probability, percent, ratio, and modeling. In addition, we have investigated how, in the context of these investigations, students use mathematics and draw on spatial analysis to develop arguments. In particular, we have found these investigations to support the remediation of foundational mathematics while also presenting complexity for learners.
